PSA: The drunk or high person doesn't care.

When they're drunk or high, obviously.

I think this PSA is intended for them... while they're sober. So they can choose to *stay* sober if they want to play the game.

Plus this PSA is tackling a common misconception, so the value of it isn't wasted if people take the time to read it especially as the young ones approach drinking/smoking age with that misconception in mind. You'd be surprised by the number of people who actually think that getting drunk/high to play LoL is a good idea.

Yes, people are really that stupid.

It is a deception.  There is no actual improvement with drugs and alcohol.  The mind is unable to compensate for the foreign chemical it's being subjected to and develops false responses as a result.  The "euphoria" that is felt is one of the ease on the symptoms of withdrawal.  

It most cases, the alcohol or drug acts as a placebo does.  People believe they are better when on the substance.  But again, that's the deception working.  But that's the trap.  Once the effect of the substance wears off, you want more of it.  That's when the addiction and damage begins.  You build up a tolerance and require greater amounts at greater intervals.  

But it makes no difference to me.  I've seen plenty of team games, not just in League, ruined by the mistakes of players who then claim that they are drunk or high as some sort of justification for their failure.  Across the board, I don't like playing with people who are inebriated nor do I care to listen to their excuses that they have willingly imbued a substance that will ultimately make them less effective then they might have been otherwise.
this ^

This reminds me of a study I read about a while back.  A group of people were asked to drive a minor obstacle course while sober.  Later, those in charge threw a party and allowed all the participates to drink as much alcohol as much as they wanted.  Then they allowed the group to drive the obstacle course again.  The group was then asked which of the two courses they felt they did their best at.  Almost 95% of the group said they did the second test better.  Of course, both sessions had been filmed.  When the group sobered up, they were shown the video of both runs.  Admittedly, the group, while drunk, failed the course across the board.  But the perception was that they did better while under the effects of alcohol.  

No doubt those that play League drunk or high have the same misconceptions.  No, it doesn't make you any better.  But it's a sure sign for me, personally, I shouldn't be playing with you.
